openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Vietnam is characterized as a developing mixed socialist-oriented market economy, combining elements of socialism with market-based mechanisms.
• Vietnam ranks as the 33rd-largest economy globally by nominal gross domestic product (GDP) and the 26th-largest by purchasing power parity (PPP).
• Classified as a lower-middle income country, Vietnam benefits from a low cost of living.

• Vietnam holds membership in major international economic organizations, including the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC), the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), and the World Trade Organization (WTO).
• Since the mid-1980s, during the Đổi Mới reform period, Vietnam transitioned from a highly centralized planned economy to a mixed economy incorporating market-oriented reforms.
• Historically, South Vietnam’s economy was dependent on U.S. aid, whereas North Vietnam and the reunified Vietnam relied on communist aid until the dissolution of the Soviet Union.
• The Vietnamese economy employs both directive and indicative planning methods through five-year plans, complemented by an open market-based economy framework.
• Over recent decades, Vietnam’s economy has experienced rapid growth and increasing integration into the global economy, particularly in the 21st century.
• The vast majority of Vietnamese enterprises are small and medium enterprises (SMEs), which form the backbone of the national economy.
• Vietnam has emerged as a leading exporter in agriculture and has become an attractive destination for foreign direct investment within Southeast Asia.

• A forecast by PricewaterhouseCoopers in February 2017 projected that Vietnam could become the fastest-growing economy worldwide, with a potential annual GDP growth rate of approximately 5.1 percent.
• Based on this growth trajectory, Vietnam’s economy was anticipated to become the 10th-largest in the world by 2050, according to the same PricewaterhouseCoopers forecast.
• Vietnam is recognized as part of the “Next Eleven” group of emerging economies, as well as the CIVETS countries, highlighting its potential for rapid economic development.

• Vietnamese civilization was fundamentally based on agriculture, with feudal dynasties consistently regarding agriculture as the primary economic foundation, and their economic philosophies rooted in physiocracy.
• Land ownership was systematically regulated, and large-scale infrastructure projects, such as dykes, were constructed in the Red River Delta to support wet rice cultivation.
• During peaceful periods, soldiers were demobilized and sent home to engage in farming activities, reflecting the agrarian focus of society.

• The royal court prohibited the slaughter of water buffalo and cattle, animals essential for agricultural labor, and conducted numerous agriculture-related ceremonies to emphasize the sector’s importance.
• While handicrafts and the arts were esteemed, commerce was looked down upon, with merchants derogatorily referred to as _con buôn_.
• Thang Long (modern-day Hanoi) served as the principal center for handicraft manufacturing in Vietnam.
• Chinese observers noted that Vietnamese commercial practices resembled those of the Chinese Song dynasty, indicating a sophisticated level of trade and business activity.
• Between the 9th and 13th centuries, Vietnam engaged in trade of ceramics and silks with regional powers including China, Champa, Western Xia, and Java.
• Archaeological findings, such as Muslim ceramics in Hanoi’s Old Quarter, provide evidence that Muslim traders resided in Hanoi from approximately the 9th to 10th centuries.
• From the 16th century onward, Confucianism’s influence waned in Vietnamese society, coinciding with the emergence of a monetary pre-capitalist economy.
• During the Lê–Mạc period, the Vietnamese state actively promoted semi-industrial businesses and maritime trade, sectors that would underpin the economy for the subsequent 250 years.

• Urban centers such as Đông Kinh and Hội An experienced rapid growth due to accelerated urbanization, although this expansion was later restricted as foreign powers perceived these cities as economic threats.
• In the 17th century, Vietnam’s economy reached its zenith, ranking as the third-largest economic power in East Asia and Southeast Asia.
• The late 18th century brought economic decline due to a combination of epidemics, natural disasters, and the devastating Tây Sơn peasant rebellion that severely damaged the country.
• In 1806, Emperor Gia Long of the Nguyễn dynasty implemented the "Sea Ban policy," which prohibited all Vietnamese overseas trade and barred Western merchants from entering Vietnam.

• The "Sea Ban policy" contributed to economic stagnation in early 19th-century Vietnam and is considered a factor leading to the country’s eventual colonization by France, though this causation remains subject to debate and verification.
• Prior to French colonization in the mid-19th century, Vietnam's economy was predominantly agrarian, subsistence-based, and centered around village life.

• The French colonial administration deliberately developed Vietnam's regions differently to serve colonial economic interests, designating the South for agricultural production due to its suitability for farming, and the North for manufacturing because of its abundant mineral resources.

• This regional economic division was exaggerated but led to the development of key exports: coal from the North and rice from the South, alongside the importation of French manufactured goods, which stimulated domestic commerce.
• The imposed separation distorted the traditional Vietnamese economy by overemphasizing regional economic differences.
• In the South, irrigated rice remained the principal subsistence crop, but the French introduced plantation agriculture cultivating tea, cotton, and tobacco.
• The colonial government developed extractive industries including mining of coal, iron, and nonferrous metals.
• Industrial development included the establishment of a shipbuilding industry in Hanoi, construction of railroads, roads, power stations, and hydraulic works.
• Agricultural development in the South focused heavily on rice cultivation, with rice and rubber becoming the main national export commodities.
• Domestic and foreign trade activities were concentrated in the Saigon-Cholon area.
• Industry in the South primarily consisted of food-processing plants and factories producing consumer goods.
• Following the political division of Vietnam in 1954, the North adopted a socialist economic system while the South pursued a capitalist model.
• The Second Indochina War (1955–1975) caused severe economic strain due to widespread destruction.
• The war resulted in approximately 1.5 million military and civilian deaths, exacerbating economic difficulties.
• The conflict also triggered an exodus of about 1 million refugees, including tens of thousands of professionals, intellectuals, technicians, and skilled workers, further weakening the economy.
• GDP per capita data (in US$/year) from 1956 to 1974 illustrates economic trends in both regions:

• The Vietnamese government's Second Five-Year Plan (1976–1981) aimed for high annual growth rates in industrial and agricultural sectors and national income, as well as integration of North and South Vietnam, but these goals were not achieved.
• During this period, Vietnam's economy remained dominated by small-scale production, low labor productivity, material and technological shortages, and insufficient food and consumer goods supply.

• The Third Five-Year Plan (1981–1985) adopted more modest goals as a compromise between ideological and pragmatic factions, emphasizing development in agriculture and industry, decentralization of planning, and improvement of government officials' managerial skills.

• After reunification in 1975, Vietnam's economy faced severe difficulties including production challenges, supply-demand imbalances, inefficient distribution and circulation, soaring inflation, and rising debt.

• Vietnam experienced a rare sharp economic deterioration during its postwar reconstruction period, resulting in one of the poorest peacetime economies globally with negative to very slow growth in national output, agriculture, and industry.
• In 1984, Vietnam's gross domestic product (GDP) was valued at US$18.1 billion, with per capita income estimated between US$200 and US$300 annually.

• Factors contributing to poor economic performance included severe climatic conditions affecting agriculture, bureaucratic mismanagement, elimination of private ownership, extinction of entrepreneurial classes in the South, and military occupation of Cambodia which led to a cutoff of international reconstruction aid.
• From the late 1970s to early 1990s, Vietnam was a member of the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance (Comecon) and heavily dependent on trade with the Soviet Union and its allies.
• Following the dissolution of Comecon and loss of traditional trading partners, Vietnam liberalized trade, devalued its exchange rate to boost exports, and pursued economic development policies.
• Between 1975 and 1994, the United States imposed a 19-year trade embargo on Vietnam, forbidding any trade during that period.
• In 1986, Vietnam launched the Đổi Mới political and economic renewal campaign, introducing reforms to transition from a centralized economy to a "socialist-oriented market economy."
• Đổi Mới combined government planning with free-market incentives, encouraged private business establishment, and promoted foreign investment including foreign-owned enterprises.
• The Vietnamese government implemented a two-child policy aimed at lowering birth rates while developing economic and social rights.
• By the late 1990s, Đổi Mới reforms had led to the creation of more than 30,000 private businesses, annual economic growth rates exceeding 7%, and a near halving of poverty levels.
• Since the early 1990s, Vietnam structurally shifted away from agriculture but without significant industrialization, instead moving toward service-oriented globalization.

• In 1990, the state sector was the primary focus for industrialization, transitioning away from bottom-up commercialization processes of the 1980s and creating supply capacity that helped avoid economic shocks after Soviet aid withdrawal.
• This supply capacity enabled rapid economic growth throughout the 1990s.
• During the 1990s, Vietnam's exports increased by 20% to 30% in some years, with exports accounting for 40% of GDP by 1999, despite the Asian economic crisis affecting other countries.

• Vietnam joined the World Trade Organization (WTO) in 2007, which eliminated textile quotas imposed by the Multi Fibre Arrangement (MFA) established in 1974 that restricted textile imports from developing countries.
• Textile quotas under the MFA expired for China and other WTO members at the end of 2004, as agreed in the 1994 Uruguay Round trade negotiations.

• A 2019 study found that Vietnam's WTO accession resulted in substantial productivity gains for private firms but had no impact on state-owned enterprises; without state-owned enterprises, overall productivity gains would have been approximately 40% larger.

• Following the 1997 Asian Financial Crisis, Vietnam adopted a cautious economic policy prioritizing macroeconomic stability over rapid growth, maintaining strong government control over key sectors such as banking, state-owned enterprises (SOEs), and foreign trade.
• Vietnam’s GDP growth declined to 6% in 1998 and further to 5% in 1999, but from 2000 onwards, the country experienced continuous real GDP growth of at least 5% annually.

• On July 13, 2000, Vietnam and the United States signed the Bilateral Trade Agreement (BTA), granting Vietnamese goods "normal trade relations" status in the U.S. market, which was expected to accelerate Vietnam’s transition to a manufacturing-based, export-oriented economy and attract foreign investment from the U.S., Europe, Asia, and other regions.

• In 2001, the Communist Party of Vietnam approved a 10-year economic plan that increased the role of the private sector while reaffirming state primacy; between 2000 and 2002, GDP growth rose to 6%-7% despite a global recession, making Vietnam the world’s second fastest-growing economy.
• During the same period (2000-2002), investment in Vietnam tripled and domestic savings increased fivefold, reflecting strong economic momentum.

• By 2003, the private sector contributed to more than 25% of all industrial output; however, between 2003 and 2005, Vietnam’s ranking in the World Economic Forum’s global competitiveness report declined sharply due to negative perceptions of government institutional effectiveness.

• Endemic official corruption, weak property rights, inefficient market regulations, and slow reforms in labor and financial markets were identified as major challenges hindering Vietnam’s competitiveness.

• From 2000 to 2004, Vietnam’s average annual GDP growth was 7.1%; in 2005, GDP growth reached 8.4%, the second highest in Asia after China, and the government estimated 8.17% growth for 2006 with a target of approximately 8.5% for 2007.

• On November 7, 2006, the World Trade Organization (WTO) General Council approved Vietnam’s accession package, and on January 11, 2007, Vietnam officially became the WTO’s 149th member after 11 years of preparation and eight years of negotiation.

• WTO accession was expected to boost Vietnam’s economy by ensuring continued liberalizing reforms and expanding trade opportunities, but also posed challenges by exposing the economy to increased foreign competition.

• Despite rapid growth exceeding 7% annually, Vietnam’s economy started from a very low base due to the long-term impacts of the Vietnam War (1950s-1970s), U.S. and allied embargoes, and post-war austerity measures.

• In 2012, the Communist Party publicly apologized for economic mismanagement following widespread bankruptcies of SOEs and rising inflation; bad debts in banks reached 15%, and GDP growth was forecasted at 5.2%, partly due to the global economic crisis.

• The government initiated economic reforms including raising the foreign ownership cap from 49% and partially privatizing SOEs, aiming to address economic downturns; by the end of 2013, plans were to privatize 25%-50% of SOEs, retaining state control only over public services and the military.
• These reforms stimulated a significant boom in the Vietnamese stock market, reflecting renewed investor confidence in the economy.

• Vietnam’s economic difficulties sparked debates about a potential new phase in its political economy, but poverty remained a primary concern as of 2018; the Provincial Governance and Public Administration Performance Index (PAPI) reported that 28% of respondents identified poverty as their main problem.

• Most survey respondents agreed that poverty reduction was essential for Vietnam to become an advanced, developed country; the proportion of the poorest respondents fearing economic deterioration rose from 13% in 2016 to 26% in 2017.
• Health insurance coverage increased from 74% in 2016 to 81% in 2017, with the most significant gains among rural populations.

• Transparency International ranked Vietnam 113th out of 176 countries and regions in 2017 for perceived corruption; a crackdown on corruption in 2016 and 2017 prosecuted numerous bankers, businesspeople, and government officials.
• PAPI data showed bribery in public district hospital services decreased from 17% in 2016 to 9% in 2017, while reports of land seizures declined from about 9% before 2013 to less than 7% in 2017.

• The percentage of respondents who believed their land was sold at fair market value dropped from 26% in 2014 to 21% in 2017; land-use graft and petty corruption, such as police bribery, remained common.
• According to journalist Ralph Jennings, Vietnam has been privatizing many state-owned operations to reduce corruption and improve efficiency.

• By March 2018, Vietnam’s economy continued robust growth, achieving its best annual growth rate in over a decade, prompting media speculation about its potential emergence as one of the "Asian Tigers."

• DBS Bank projected in 2019 that Vietnam’s economy could grow at 6.0%-6.5% annually by 2029, with potential to surpass Singapore’s economy within the next decade due to strong foreign investment inflows and productivity growth; Vietnam reportedly surpassed Singapore’s economy just one year later.
• In the early 2020s, despite trade wars with major partners, the COVID-19 pandemic, and global deglobalization trends, Vietnam remained Asia’s top-performing economy.

• Since 2000, Vietnam has shifted to manufacturing higher-value goods with better-paying jobs supported by a more skilled workforce; electronics accounted for 38% of exports in 2020, up from 14% in 2010.
• Vietnam achieved an average economic growth rate of 6.2% in recent years, second only to China in Asia.
• Foreign investment in luxury hotels and resorts was expected to increase to support the expanding tourism industry.
• The table presents Vietnam's main economic indicators from 1990 to 2023, including IMF staff estimations for 2021–2027, with inflation rates below 5% highlighted in green.

• In 1990, Vietnam's real GDP growth was 5.0%, nominal GDP was US$8.2 billion, GDP (PPP) was US$77.7 billion, GDP per capita nominal was US$121.7, GDP per capita PPP was US$1151.2, inflation rate was 36.0%, unemployment rate was 12.3%, and government debt data was not available.
• The highest inflation rate recorded was 81.8% in 1991, with a GDP growth of 5.8% and nominal GDP of US$9.7 billion.
• Vietnam experienced strong GDP growth in the 1990s, peaking at 9.5% in 1995 with a nominal GDP of US$26.4 billion and inflation at 16.9%.
• Inflation rates dropped below 5% for the first time in 1997 at 3.1%, coinciding with 8.2% GDP growth and nominal GDP of US$34.1 billion.
• From 2000 onwards, government debt as a percentage of GDP is recorded, starting at 24.8% in 2000 with a GDP growth of 6.8% and nominal GDP of US$39.6 billion.
• Vietnam's nominal GDP increased steadily, reaching US$98.4 billion in 2007 with 7.1% growth, inflation at 8.3%, unemployment at 4.6%, and government debt at 32.2% of GDP.
• The inflation rate peaked again at 23.1% in 2008, despite a GDP growth slowdown to 5.7% and nominal GDP of US$124.8 billion.
• Post-2008 global financial crisis, GDP growth stabilized around 5.4% to 7.8% with inflation fluctuating between 3.3% and 18.7% through 2011.
• Government debt rose from 24.8% in 2000 to a peak of 47.5% in 2016, before gradually declining to 33.5% projected in 2024.
• GDP per capita nominal increased from US$121.7 in 1990 to an estimated US$4622.5 in 2024, while GDP per capita PPP rose from US$1151.2 to an estimated US$15469.9 in the same period.
• Unemployment rates declined significantly from 12.3% in 1990 to around 2.0%–2.3% in recent years, with a slight increase to 3.2% in 2021 due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
• Vietnam's real GDP growth slowed to 2.6% in 2021 amid the pandemic but rebounded to 8.0% in 2022 and is projected at 6.2% in 2024.
• Nominal GDP reached US$433.7 billion in 2023 and is projected to increase to US$465.8 billion in 2024.
• Inflation rates have stabilized below 5% since 2014, except for minor fluctuations, with 3.7% projected in 2024.

• The data reflects Vietnam's transition from high inflation and unemployment in the early 1990s to sustained economic growth, controlled inflation, reduced unemployment, and manageable government debt levels in recent years.
• Vietnam is the world's third-largest rice exporter, with rice terraces notably present in Sa Pa.
• Vietnam ranks as the world's second-largest coffee producer and exporter, following Brazil.
• The country is the world's largest exporter of cashew nuts.
• In 2003, Vietnam produced an estimated 30.7 million cubic meters of wood, with sawn wood production at 2,950 cubic meters.
• Due to dwindling forests, Vietnam imposed a ban on the export of logs and raw timber in 1992.
• In 1997, the export ban was extended to all timber products except wooden artifacts.
• During the 1990s, Vietnam initiated a tree-planting program to reclaim land for forests.
• Vietnam’s fishing industry benefits from a long coastline and extensive rivers and lakes, experiencing moderate growth overall.
• In 2003, the total fish catch was approximately 2.6 million tons.
• Seafood exports increased fourfold between 1990 and 2002, reaching over US$2 billion, driven largely by shrimp farms in the South and catfish production.
• Vietnamese catfish, distinct from American species, are marketed in the U.S. under the same name, leading to U.S. anti-dumping complaints.
• The U.S. imposed tariffs on Vietnamese catfish imports and considered tariffs on shrimp.
• In 2005, Vietnam’s seafood industry shifted focus toward domestic demand to offset declining exports.
• Vietnam’s rice export quality suffers due to the limited sophistication of small-scale farmers despite being a top rice exporter.
• In 2018, Vietnam produced 44.0 million tons of rice, ranking 5th globally behind China, India, Indonesia, and Bangladesh.
• The country produced 17.9 million tons of sugarcane in 2018, ranking 16th worldwide.
• Vegetable production in 2018 was 14.8 million tons.
• Cassava production reached 9.8 million tons in 2018, making Vietnam the 7th largest producer globally.
• Maize production was 4.8 million tons in 2018.
• Cashew nut production was 2.6 million tons in 2018, making Vietnam the largest producer worldwide.
• Banana production was 2.0 million tons in 2018, ranking 20th globally.
• Coffee production in 2018 was 1.6 million tons, ranking Vietnam 2nd in the world after Brazil.
• Coconut production was 1.5 million tons in 2018, ranking 6th globally.
• Sweet potato production was 1.3 million tons in 2018, ranking 9th worldwide.
• Watermelon production was 1.2 million tons in 2018.
• Natural rubber production was 1.1 million tons in 2018, ranking 3rd globally behind Thailand and Indonesia.
• Orange production was 852 thousand tons in 2018, ranking 18th worldwide.
• Mango production, including mangosteen and guava, was 779 thousand tons in 2018.
• Pineapple production was 654 thousand tons in 2018, ranking 12th globally.
• Tea production was 270 thousand tons in 2018, ranking 6th worldwide.
• Vietnam also produces smaller quantities of various other agricultural products.
• In 2018, Vietnam was the world’s 5th largest pork producer with 3.8 million tons.
• The country produced 839 thousand tons of chicken meat in 2018.
• Beef production in 2018 was 334 thousand tons.
• Cow’s milk production reached 936 million liters in 2018.
• Honey production was 20 thousand tons in 2018.
• The Dau Tieng Solar Power Complex is recognized as the largest solar farm in Southeast Asia, marking a significant development in the region's renewable energy infrastructure.
• Petroleum serves as Vietnam's primary energy source, with coal being the secondary source, contributing approximately 25% of the country's energy supply when excluding biomass.
• Vietnam's oil reserves are estimated to range between 270 and 500 million tons, indicating substantial but finite petroleum resources.

• Oil production in Vietnam increased rapidly to 403,300 barrels per day (64,120 m³/d) by 2004; however, this output is believed to have peaked at that time and is expected to decline gradually in subsequent years.

• In 2003, the mining and quarrying sector contributed 9.4% to Vietnam's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) and employed 0.7% of the national workforce, highlighting its economic and employment significance.
• The main mineral exports of Vietnam include petroleum and coal, with additional mining activities producing antimony, bauxite, chromium, gold, iron, natural phosphates, tin, and zinc.
• By 2019, Vietnam ranked as the 9th largest global producer of antimony, 10th in tin production, 11th in bauxite, 12th in titanium, 13th in manganese, and 9th in phosphate production worldwide.
• Vietnam is also among the world's largest producers of precious gemstones such as ruby, sapphire, topaz, and spinel, underscoring its mineral diversity.

• Crude oil was Vietnam's leading export commodity until the late 2000s; however, by 2014, high-tech electrical manufactures had become the dominant export sector, with crude oil comprising only 5% of exports compared to 20% in 1996.
• The peak of crude oil export earnings occurred in 2004 when crude oil accounted for 22% of Vietnam's total export revenues.

• Vietnam exports petroleum primarily in crude form due to its limited refining capacity; the only operational refinery as of the early 2000s was located at Cat Hai near Ho Chi Minh City, with a capacity of merely 800 barrels per day (130 m³/d).
• Refined petroleum products constituted 10.2% of Vietnam's total imports in 2002, reflecting the country's dependence on imported refined fuels.
• As of 2012, Vietnam operated the Dung Quat refinery, with plans to construct a second refinery, the Nghi Son Refinery, scheduled to begin construction in May 2013.
• Vietnam's anthracite coal reserves are estimated at 3.7 billion tons, indicating a substantial coal resource base.
• Coal production increased from 9.6 million tons in 1999 to nearly 19 million tons in 2003, demonstrating rapid growth in coal mining activities.
• Potential natural gas reserves in Vietnam are estimated at 1.3 trillion cubic meters, with 2.26 billion cubic meters of natural gas brought ashore in 2002.
• Hydroelectric power represents another significant energy source for Vietnam, contributing to the country's energy mix.
• In 2004, Vietnam confirmed plans to develop nuclear power plants with international assistance: one with Russian support and a second planned with a Japanese consortium.

• From 2019 onwards, Vietnam experienced accelerated deployment of renewable energy, notably surpassing other Southeast Asian countries, with most new capacity coming from solar and wind power plants.
• By 2023, the expansion of renewable energy in Vietnam slowed considerably due to limitations in electrical grid capacity and a reduction in government support policies.

• Vietnam's total energy consumption in Terawatt-hours (TWh) increased significantly over the decades: 91 TWh in 1970, 54 TWh in 1980, 77 TWh in 1990, 214 TWh in 2000, 540 TWh in 2010, 1,204 TWh in 2020, and 1,359 TWh in 2023.

• Per capita energy consumption in Kilowatt-hours (KWh) also rose markedly: 2,162 KWh in 1970, 1,022 KWh in 1980, 1,153 KWh in 1990, 2,711 KWh in 2000, 6,180 KWh in 2010, 12,462 KWh in 2020, and 13,744 KWh in 2023, reflecting increased energy use per individual over time.
• VinFast, recognized as Vietnam's first global automaker, operates its manufacturing facility in Hải Phòng.
• In 2004, the industrial sector contributed 40.1% to Vietnam's GDP but employed only 12.9% of the workforce.
• By the year 2000, non-state activities accounted for 22.4% of industrial production in Vietnam.
• Between 1994 and 2004, the industrial sector in Vietnam experienced an average annual growth rate of 10.3%.
• Manufacturing contributed 20.3% of Vietnam's GDP in 2004 and employed 10.2% of the workforce during the same year.
• From 1994 to 2004, manufacturing GDP grew at an average annual rate of 11.2%, indicating robust expansion in this sector.
• The leading manufacturing sectors in Vietnam include electronics, food processing, cigarettes and tobacco, textiles, chemicals, and footwear goods, all of which experienced rapid growth.

• Vietnam benefits from its geographical proximity to China combined with lower labor costs, positioning it as an emerging manufacturing hub in Asia, particularly attracting Korean and Japanese firms.
• Samsung produces approximately 40% of its phones in Vietnam, highlighting the country's importance in global electronics manufacturing.
• As of 2019, Samsung employed over 200,000 workers in the Hanoi area to produce smartphones, while also outsourcing some manufacturing to China and producing large portions of its phones in India.
• LG Electronics relocated its smartphone production from South Korea to Vietnam to maintain competitiveness, citing Vietnam's "abundant labor force" as a key motivation for the move.
• In the first seven months of 2024, Samsung accounted for 15% of Vietnam's exports, marking a decrease from 22.7% in 2017, yet remaining a significant contributor to the country's export economy.
• Over the past decade, Vietnam has developed a significant automotive industry, although specific details and citations are not provided.
• In 2004, the service sector contributed 38.2% to Vietnam's gross domestic product (GDP).
• Between 1994 and 2004, the GDP generated by the service sector in Vietnam experienced an average annual growth rate of 6.0%.
• In 2012, Vietnam received 6.8 million international visitors, with expectations to surpass 7 million in 2013, indicating its growing appeal as a tourist destination.

• According to TripAdvisor's 2013 Travelers' Choice list of the top 25 destinations in Asia, four Vietnamese cities—Hanoi, Ho Chi Minh City, Hoi An, and Ha Long—were featured, highlighting their popularity among travelers.
• The year 2016 marked a milestone for Vietnam as it received over 10 million international visitors for the first time, initiating a continuous upward trend in tourist arrivals.

• By 2019, Vietnam attracted 18 million international visitors, ranking as the fifth most visited country in the Asia-Pacific region according to the World Tourism rankings published by the United Nations World Tourism Organization.
• The COVID-19 pandemic severely impacted Vietnam’s tourism sector, with the government suspending all tourist visa issuances from March 2020.
• In April 2020, Vietnam experienced a 98% year-on-year decline in foreign visitor numbers due to pandemic-related restrictions.
• Total tourism revenues in Vietnam dropped by over 60% year-on-year in July 2020, reflecting the significant economic impact of the pandemic on the tourism industry.
• Vietnam reopened its borders to international arrivals in March 2022, signaling the beginning of recovery for the tourism sector.
• In the first six months of 2024, Vietnam recorded 6,943,961 tourist arrivals, representing a 65.7% increase compared to the same period in 2023, demonstrating strong growth in tourism recovery.

• The export of labour, defined as the deployment of Vietnamese workers to foreign countries for employment, constitutes a significant component of the Vietnamese economy due to the remittances these workers send back to Vietnam.
• The COVID-19 pandemic caused a disruption in the export of labour from Vietnam, impacting the flow of workers abroad and consequently the associated economic benefits.
• By the year 2022, Vietnam set a target to send approximately 90,000 workers overseas, indicating a recovery and expansion effort in the labour export sector post-pandemic.
• Historically, the primary destination countries for Vietnamese labour export have included South Korea, Japan, Malaysia, and the Republic of China (Taiwan).
• In recent developments, Vietnam is strategically aiming to expand its labour export markets to include Germany, Russia, and Israel, diversifying its traditional destinations.

• The State Bank of Vietnam, headquartered in Ho Chi Minh City (formerly Saigon), serves as the central bank responsible for regulating the country’s monetary policy and overseeing the banking system.
• Ho Chi Minh City hosts the Ho Chi Minh City Stock Exchange (HOSE), which is a major financial institution facilitating the trading of stocks and securities in Vietnam.

• The banking and finance sector in Vietnam is anchored by these two key institutions: the State Bank of Vietnam as the regulatory authority and the Ho Chi Minh City Stock Exchange as the primary marketplace for equity trading.
• The Vietnamese banking sector is predominantly dominated by state-owned banks, with VietinBank, BIDV, and Vietcombank identified as the most important institutions in the industry.
• There is a notable trend of foreign investment in Vietnam's banking sector, particularly in profitable banks, exemplified by Bank of Tokyo Mitsubishi UFJ owning 19.73% of VietinBank.
• Similarly, Mizuho holds a 15% ownership stake in Vietcombank, reflecting significant foreign participation in major Vietnamese banks.
• As of December 31, 2020, the top five Vietnamese banks by authorised capital are ranked as follows:
• The authorised capital figures are based on average exchange rates for the year 2020, with 1 USD equaling 23,286 VND, as sourced from tradingeconomics.com.
• Vietnam operates two primary stock trading centers: the Ho Chi Minh City Securities Trading Center and the Hanoi Securities Trading Center.
• The Ho Chi Minh City Securities Trading Center manages the Ho Chi Minh Stock Exchange (HOSE).
• The Hanoi Securities Trading Center manages the Hanoi Stock Exchange (HNX).
• In addition to these two exchanges, there is a third market known as the Unlisted Public Companies Market (UPCOM), which operates as part of the Hanoi Stock Exchange.
• Collectively, the two trading centers and the three exchanges (HOSE, HNX, and UPCOM) fall under the jurisdiction of the Vietnam Stock Exchange (VSE).
• The Vietnam Stock Exchange (VSE) is a legislated entity established and regulated under the Law on Securities enacted in 2019.
• The VSE operates under the supervision of the State Securities Commission (SSC), which is a governmental body functioning as a branch of the Ministry of Finance.
• The official currency of Vietnam is the đồng, which is abbreviated as VND or represented by the symbol đ.

• In 2022, countries and territories were ranked by their Gross Domestic Product (GDP) per capita using nominal values, providing a comparative measure of economic output per person without adjusting for purchasing power differences.

• Additionally, in 2022, countries and territories were also ranked by GDP per capita based on Purchasing Power Parity (PPP), which adjusts for relative cost of living and inflation rates to offer a more accurate comparison of economic well-being across nations.
• The exchange rate between the U.S. dollar and the Vietnamese đồng is significant due to the đồng not being freely convertible on international markets.

• The Vietnamese đồng is loosely pegged to the U.S. dollar through a mechanism known as a "crawling peg," which permits gradual adjustments in the exchange rate in response to changing market conditions.
• Under the crawling peg system, the exchange rate was initially allowed to fluctuate within a band of 3 percent above or below a fixed rate set daily by the State Bank of Vietnam (SBV).
• In October 2022, the fluctuation band was widened from 3 percent to 5 percent on either side of the fixed daily rate determined by the SBV.
• As of December 27, 2024, the official exchange rate stands at 1 U.S. dollar equaling 25,448 Vietnamese đồng.

• Despite the prominence of the đồng and the U.S. dollar in Vietnam’s currency system, gold continues to hold a role as a physical currency to some extent, although its economic significance has diminished in recent years.
• In the 1980s, Vietnam experienced high inflation driven by excessive demand for industrial sector development, food, and other commodities.
• To stimulate supply during this period, the Vietnamese government attempted to co-integrate the parallel market with the planned market.
• Initial reforms in the 1980s increased total output; however, due to partial implementation, the Consumer Price Index (CPI) inflation rate surged to 200% in 1982.
• To address the inflation surge, the government introduced forced savings, a policy aimed at accumulating unspent money to reduce monetary overhang.
• Vietnam underwent a period of hyperinflation particularly between 1987 and 1992, coinciding with the early years of its extensive economic reform program.
• By the first half of 2008, inflation was recorded at 20.3%, significantly higher than the 3.4% inflation rate in 2000 but markedly lower than the 160% inflation rate experienced in 1988.
• Inflation rates were 11.5% in 2010 and increased to 18.58% in 2011.
• At the end of 2012, inflation decreased substantially to 7.5%, marking a significant reduction from the previous year.
• Inflation continued to decline to 6% in 2013 and further to 4.09% in 2014.
• By 2016, inflation had been reduced to a low level of only 2%.

• From 1991 to February 2018, Vietnamese companies participated in approximately 4,000 mergers and acquisitions transactions, either as acquirors or targets, with a total cumulative value of 40.6 billion USD.

• Foreign companies demonstrated significant interest in the Vietnamese market through 1,120 inbound deals, collectively valued at nearly 15 billion USD, indicating a strong trend of market entry or expansion via mergers and acquisitions.

• The mergers and acquisitions sector in Vietnam has encountered multiple challenges that have negatively impacted the success rate of transactions; these obstacles primarily stem from cultural differences, lack of transparency, and complex legal frameworks.

• The Institute for Mergers, Acquisitions and Alliances, active in Vietnam since 2006, along with M&A expert Christopher Kummer, forecasted a decline in the mergers and acquisitions trend in 2018 following peak activity in 2016 and 2017.
• The largest and most notable mergers and acquisitions deals in Vietnam since 2000 include:
• On December 19, 2017, Vietnam Beverage Co. Ltd. (Vietnam) acquired Sabeco (Vietnam) for 4,838.49 million USD.
• On February 16, 2012, Perenco SA (France) acquired ConocoPhillips Co-Oil & Gas Asset (Vietnam) for 1,290.00 million USD.
• On April 29, 2016, Central Group of Companies (Thailand) acquired Casino Guichard-Perrachon-BigC (Vietnam) for 1,135.33 million USD.
• On December 25, 2015, Singha Asia Holding Pte Ltd. (Singapore) acquired Masan Consumer Corporation (Vietnam) for 1,100.00 million USD.
• On February 13, 2015, China Steel Asia Pacific Holding Pte Ltd. (Singapore) acquired Formosa Ha Tinh (Cayman) Ltd. (Vietnam) for 939.00 million USD.
• On August 7, 2014, Berli Jucker Public Company Limited (Thailand) acquired Metro Cash & Carry Vietnam Co (Vietnam) for 875.20 million USD.
• On December 27, 2012, Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ Ltd. (Japan) acquired VietinBank (Vietnam) for 742.34 million USD.
• On April 17, 2015, TCC Land International Pte Ltd. (Singapore) acquired Metro Cash & Carry Vietnam Co (Vietnam) for 705.14 million USD.
• On October 5, 2011, Vincom Joint Stock Company (Vietnam) acquired Vinpearl Joint Stock Company (Vietnam) for 649.39 million USD.
• On January 28, 2016, Masan Group Corporation (Vietnam) acquired Masan Consumer Corporation (Vietnam) for 600.00 million USD.
• All of the top 10 largest mergers and acquisitions deals listed are inbound transactions into Vietnam, with no outbound deals among them.

• Saigon Port is the busiest container port in Vietnam and has the capability to accommodate post-Panamax ships, indicating its capacity to handle large, modern vessels beyond the size limits of the original Panama Canal locks.

• Economic relations between Vietnam and the United States have been improving, marked by a landmark bilateral agreement reached in December 2001 that facilitated an increase in Vietnam's exports to the U.S.; however, challenges remain due to disagreements over textile and catfish exports which hinder the full implementation of this agreement.

• Additional complications in U.S.-Vietnam economic relations include efforts by the U.S. Congress to link non-humanitarian aid to Vietnam’s human rights record, as well as ongoing bilateral discussions addressing barriers to trade and intellectual property rights.

• Vietnam places high importance on its economic relationship with China, especially given China’s rapid economic growth; after resolving most territorial disputes, trade between Vietnam and China has expanded quickly, with Vietnam importing more products from China in 2004 than from any other country.

• In November 2004, the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), of which Vietnam is a member, and China announced plans to establish the world’s largest free-trade area by 2010, aiming to enhance regional economic integration.
• Vietnam officially became a member of the World Trade Organization (WTO) on January 11, 2007, marking a significant step in integrating its economy into the global trading system.

• In December 2015, Vietnam joined the ASEAN Economic Community alongside the other nine ASEAN member states; this community aims to integrate the ten members to facilitate freer flow of labor, investment, and trade within the region.

• Vietnam is currently navigating complex economic relationships influenced by multiple global and regional powers, including Russia, China, and the United States, as it seeks to achieve economic multilateralization.

• Regionally, Vietnam is influenced by economic ties with China, South Korea, Japan, and ASEAN countries, as well as other key constituents such as Taiwan, Hong Kong, Australia, New Zealand, and India, reflecting its involvement in broader regional frameworks such as ASEAN+3 and ASEAN+6.
• Since the implementation of Đổi Mới reforms in 1986, Vietnam has experienced consistent double-digit growth in both exports and imports, significantly increasing its foreign trade volume.
• After joining the World Trade Organization (WTO) in 2007, concerns were raised domestically regarding Vietnam’s trade account deficits, which persisted in the following years.
• Between 2007 and 2012, Vietnam ran substantial trade deficits with the rest of the world, reaching a record deficit of US$18 billion in 2008.
• The trade account deficit began to improve after 2008, culminating in Vietnam recording its first trade surplus since 1993 in 2012, amounting to US$780 million.
• In 2012, total trade reached US$228.13 billion, marking a 12.1% increase compared to 2011.
• Vietnam continued to record trade surpluses in subsequent years, with a surplus of US$863 million in 2013, representing the second consecutive year of surplus.
• In 2014, Vietnam achieved its largest trade surplus in history at US$2.14 billion, marking the third consecutive year of surplus.
• The trade surplus record was surpassed in 2017, when Vietnam recorded a surplus of US$2.92 billion.
• Detailed trade statistics from 2001 to 2024 show a steady increase in total trade, exports, and imports, with fluctuations in trade balances as follows:
• In 2001, total trade was US$31.20 billion, with exports at US$15.00 billion and imports at US$16.20 billion, resulting in a trade deficit of US$1.2 billion.
• By 2007, total trade had grown to US$111.30 billion, exports to US$48.6 billion (22.1% increase), imports to US$62.7 billion (39.6% increase), and a trade deficit of US$14.1 billion.
• The peak trade deficit occurred in 2008 at US$18 billion, with total trade of US$143.40 billion, exports of US$62.7 billion (29.0% increase), and imports of US$80.7 billion (28.7% increase).
• The deficit decreased in 2009 to US$12.9 billion, with total trade of US$127 billion, exports of US$57.1 billion (-8.9% change), and imports of US$69.9 billion (-13.4% change).
• From 2010 onwards, exports and imports steadily increased, with exports reaching US$96.91 billion and imports US$106.75 billion in 2011, resulting in a deficit of US$9.84 billion.
• In 2012, Vietnam recorded a trade surplus of US$780 million with exports of US$114.57 billion (18.2% increase) and imports of US$113.79 billion (6.6% increase).
• The trade surplus continued in 2013 (US$863 million) and 2014 (US$2.14 billion), with exports and imports growing at rates between 12.1% and 15.4%.
• In 2015, Vietnam experienced a trade deficit of US$3.54 billion despite total trade increasing to US$327.76 billion.
• The trade surplus returned in 2016 at US$2.68 billion, with exports of US$175.94 billion and imports of US$173.26 billion.

• In 2017, the trade surplus reached a new high of US$2.92 billion, with total trade at US$425.12 billion, exports at US$214.01 billion (21.2% increase), and imports at US$211.1 billion (20.8% increase).
• The surplus expanded further in 2018 to US$6.8 billion, with total trade of US$480.17 billion, exports of US$243.48 billion (13.2% increase), and imports of US$236.69 billion (11.1% increase).
• In 2019, the trade surplus increased to US$11.12 billion, with exports at US$264.189 billion (8.4% increase) and imports at US$253.071 billion (6.8% increase).
• The surplus rose significantly in 2020 to US$19.95 billion, with exports of US$282.65 billion (7% increase) and imports of US$262.7 billion (3.7% increase).

• Projections or data for 2024 indicate total trade reaching US$786.29 billion, exports at US$405.53 billion (14.3% increase), imports at US$380.76 billion (16.7% increase), and a trade surplus of US$24.77 billion.

• Overall, Vietnam’s foreign trade has demonstrated robust growth since 1986, transitioning from persistent trade deficits to sustained trade surpluses in the 2010s, reflecting the country’s increasing integration into the global economy and successful export expansion strategies.
• In 2004, Vietnam's merchandise exports were valued at US$26.5 billion and were experiencing rapid growth alongside imports.
• The principal exports of Vietnam in 2004 included crude oil (22.1%), textiles and garments (17.1%), footwear (10.5%), fisheries products (9.4%), and electronics (4.1%).
• The main export destinations for Vietnam in 2004 were the United States (18.8%), Japan (13.2%), China (10.3%), Australia (6.9%), Singapore (5.2%), Germany (4.0%), and the United Kingdom (3.8%).
• In 2012, Vietnam's exports rose by 18.2%, reaching a total value of US$114.57 billion.

• The primary export markets for Vietnam in 2012 included the European Union (US$20 billion), the United States (US$19 billion), ASEAN countries (US$17.8 billion), Japan (US$13.9 billion), China (US$14.2 billion), and South Korea (US$7 billion).
• In 2013, exports increased by 15.4%, valued at US$132.17 billion, with electronics exports comprising 24.5% of total exports, a significant rise from 4.4% in 2008.
• Textiles and garments remained a crucial export sector in 2013, valued at approximately US$17.9 billion.

• In 2014, exports grew by 13.6%, reaching US$150.1 billion, with electronics and electronics parts, textiles and garments, and computers and computer parts identified as the three main export groups.
• The United States continued to be Vietnam's largest export market in 2014, with exports valued at US$28.5 billion.

• The European Union was the second largest export market in 2014, with US$27.9 billion in exports, followed by ASEAN countries in third place, China in fourth, and Japan as the fifth largest export market.

• In 2024, Vietnam's exports increased by 14.3 percent, with major export commodities including garments and textiles (US$37 billion), electronics (US$72.6 billion), plastics (US$11.8 billion), and furniture (US$3.4 billion).
• In 2004, Vietnam's merchandise imports were valued at US$31.5 billion and exhibited rapid growth.
• The principal import categories in 2004 included machinery (17.5%), refined petroleum (11.5%), steel (8.3%), materials for the textile industry (7.2%), and cloth (6.0%).
• The main countries of origin for Vietnam's imports in 2004 were China (13.9%), Taiwan (11.6%), Singapore (11.3%), Japan (11.1%), South Korea (10.4%), Thailand (5.8%), and Malaysia (3.8%).
• By 2012, Vietnam's import value increased by 6.6%, reaching US$113.79 billion.

• Major import partners in 2012 included China with US$29.2 billion, ASEAN countries collectively at US$22.3 billion, South Korea at US$16.2 billion, Japan at US$13.7 billion, the European Union (EU) at US$10 billion, and the United States at US$6.3 billion.
• In 2014, Vietnam's imports rose by 12.1%, reaching a total value of US$148 billion, with the majority consisting of materials and machinery essential for export production.
• China remained Vietnam's largest import partner in 2014, with imports valued at US$43.7 billion.
• The ASEAN region was the second largest import source in 2014, with imports totaling US$23.1 billion.
• South Korea ranked third, Japan fourth, and the European Union fifth among Vietnam's largest import partners in 2014.

sections.section_name: External debt, foreign aid and foreign investment
openai_summarised_points: • In 2004, Vietnam's external debt amounted to US$16.6 billion, representing 37% of the country's GDP.
• Between 1988 and December 2004, cumulative foreign direct investment (FDI) commitments in Vietnam totaled US$46 billion, with approximately 58% of this amount disbursed by the end of 2004.
• Around half of the FDI was concentrated in the two major urban centers of Ho Chi Minh City and Hanoi, highlighting the geographic focus of foreign investment.
• In 2003, new foreign direct investment commitments reached US$1.5 billion, indicating ongoing investor interest.

• The industry and construction sectors received the largest share of licensed FDI, followed by oil and gas, fisheries, agriculture and forestry, transportation and communications, and hotels and tourism.
• From 2006 to 2010, Vietnam aimed to attract US$18 billion in FDI to support a targeted economic growth rate exceeding 7%.

• Despite increasing FDI inflows, foreign investors perceived Vietnam as a risky investment destination, as evidenced by a survey conducted by the Japan External Trade Organization among Japanese companies operating in Vietnam.
• Survey respondents cited high costs of utilities, office rentals, and skilled labor as significant challenges to investment.
• Additional obstacles identified by the U.S. State Department included corruption, bureaucratic inefficiencies, lack of transparent regulations, and inadequate enforcement of investor rights.
• In 2004, Vietnam was ranked tied for 102nd place in Transparency International's Corruption Perceptions Index, reflecting concerns about corruption levels.
• A study on foreign investment and corruption in Vietnam found that foreign firms had a higher propensity to engage in bribery when entering restricted sectors.
• The study also concluded that removing investment restrictions reduced bribery by increasing the number of Foreign Investment Enterprises and fostering competition within sectors.

• The World Bank’s assistance program for Vietnam focuses on three main objectives: supporting the transition to a market economy, enhancing equitable and sustainable development, and promoting good governance.
• From 1993 through 2004, Vietnam received pledges totaling US$29 billion in official development assistance (ODA), with about US$14 billion (49%) disbursed during this period.
• In 2004, international donors pledged US$2.25 billion in ODA to Vietnam, of which US$1.65 billion was actually disbursed.
• Three donors—Japan, the World Bank, and the Asian Development Bank—accounted for 80% of ODA disbursements in 2004.
• For the period 2006 to 2010, Vietnam anticipated receiving between US$14 billion and US$15 billion in ODA.
• Pledged foreign direct investment increased to US$21.3 billion in 2007 and reached a record US$31.6 billion in the first half of 2008.
• Mergers and acquisitions became an increasingly important channel for investment in Vietnam’s economy, particularly after 2005.
• In 2023, Vietnam realized foreign direct investment inflows amounting to US$23.2 billion and recorded an additional US$36.6 billion in registered FDI commitments.
• Vietnam is a member of the ASEAN Free Trade Area (AFTA), which facilitates trade among ASEAN countries.

• The ASEAN–Australia–New Zealand Free Trade Area (AANZFTA) is a free trade agreement between ASEAN and the Australia-New Zealand Closer Economic Relations Trade Agreement (ANZCERTA) countries, signed on 27 February 2009 and effective from 1 January 2010; detailed information on AANZFTA is available online.
• The ASEAN–China Free Trade Area (ACFTA) has been in effect since 1 January 2010, promoting trade between ASEAN countries, including Vietnam, and China.
• The ASEAN–India Free Trade Area (AIFTA) came into effect on 1 January 2010, enhancing trade relations between ASEAN members and India.
• The ASEAN–Japan Comprehensive Economic Partnership (AJCEP) is a trade agreement between ASEAN countries and Japan, facilitating economic cooperation.
• The ASEAN–Korea Free Trade Area (AKFTA) has been operational since 1 January 2010, strengthening trade ties between ASEAN nations and South Korea.
• Vietnam participates in the Comprehensive Economic Partnership for East Asia, a broader regional economic integration initiative.
• Vietnam is a party to the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), a multilateral trade agreement among Pacific Rim countries.
• On 29 May 2015, Vietnam signed a Free Trade Agreement (FTA) with the Eurasian Economic Union, which includes Russia and other member states, enhancing trade cooperation.
• The European Union-Vietnam Free Trade Agreement (EVFTA) came into effect on 1 August 2020, significantly boosting trade between Vietnam and EU member countries.
• The Vietnam-Chile Free Trade Agreement (VCFTA) has been effective since 1 January 2014, facilitating bilateral trade between Vietnam and Chile.
• The Vietnam-Korea Free Trade Agreement (VKFTA) came into force on 20 December 2015, strengthening economic ties between Vietnam and South Korea.
• The Japan-Vietnam Economic Partnership Agreement was implemented on 1 October 2009, promoting economic collaboration between the two nations.
• The United Kingdom-Vietnam Free Trade Agreement became effective on 1 January 2021, ensuring continued trade relations post-Brexit.

• The section on Vietnam's economic development strategy currently lacks sufficient citations for verification, indicating that the information presented may not be fully supported by reliable sources as of May 2025.

• Readers and contributors are encouraged to improve the article by adding citations from trustworthy references to enhance the credibility and accuracy of the content related to Vietnam's economic development strategy.
• Unsourced material in this section is subject to challenge and potential removal to maintain the integrity and reliability of the information provided about Vietnam's economy.
• Over the past 30 years, Vietnam has signed numerous trade agreements with various partners, establishing itself as one of the main manufacturing hubs globally.
• In 1995, Vietnam became a member of the ASEAN community, marking a significant step in regional economic integration.
• In 2000, Vietnam signed a free trade agreement with the United States, enhancing bilateral trade relations.
• Vietnam was admitted to the World Trade Organization (WTO) in 2007, further integrating into the global economy.
• Following WTO admission, Vietnam pursued bilateral trade agreements with other ASEAN countries, China, India, Japan, and Korea, among others, to deepen economic ties.

• Vietnam has actively collaborated with partners to ratify the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CP TPP), also known as TPP-11, after the United States withdrew from the original Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP).
• The CP TPP aims to promote economic cooperation, regional connectivity, and economic growth among member countries.
• The World Bank estimates that the CP TPP would increase Vietnam’s GDP by 1.1% by 2030, alongside a boost in productivity.
• These trade liberalization efforts have resulted in lowered tariffs on both imports and exports involving Vietnam.
• Vietnam’s trade balance improved, achieving a surplus of $2.8 billion during the first eight months of 2018, according to the Vietnam Customs Department.
• On June 30, 2019, after 10 years of negotiation, Vietnam signed the Free Trade Agreement and Investment Protection Agreement with the European Union (EU).
• Vietnam became only the fourth Asian country to sign such an agreement with the EU, following Japan, South Korea, and Singapore.

• In 1986, the Vietnamese government enacted its first Law on Foreign Investment, marking a significant policy shift by allowing foreign companies to operate within Vietnam, reflecting a broader effort to adopt a more open market economy.

• From 1981 to 2005, Vietnam developed a new intellectual property law framework that progressively abandoned the Soviet-style collective ownership model, signaling a move toward modernizing legal protections for intellectual property.

• A key milestone in Vietnam’s intellectual property reform was the 1997 Copyright Agreement with the United States, primarily aimed at preventing Vietnam from becoming an international hub for illegal copying, thereby aligning Vietnam’s IP laws more closely with international standards.

• The Vietnamese constitution and related laws have undergone regular revisions to create a more investor-friendly business environment, focusing on reducing bureaucratic red tape and accelerating the inflow of foreign investment.

• According to the World Economic Forum’s Global Competitiveness Report, Vietnam improved its global ranking from 77th place in 2006 to 55th place in 2017, indicating enhanced competitiveness in the international market.
• The World Bank’s Ease of Doing Business rankings also reflected Vietnam’s progress, with the country advancing from 104th place in 2007 to 68th place in 2017.

• The World Bank specifically praised Vietnam for improvements in several areas, including contract enforcement, increased access to credit, development of basic infrastructure, and facilitation of trade, all contributing to a more conducive business environment.
• As of 2024, Vietnam's population reached 100 million, a significant increase from 60 million in 1986, with more than half of the population under the age of 35.
• Vietnam made substantial public investments in education, prioritizing universal and compulsory primary education to support its export-led growth strategy.
• The emphasis on literacy and education was crucial for developing a skilled mass workforce necessary for growth in the manufacturing sector.
• Concurrently, Vietnam invested heavily in physical infrastructure to provide affordable mass access to essential services such as electricity, water, and particularly the internet.
• The combined investment in human capital and infrastructure facilitated Vietnam's emergence as a major hub for foreign investment and manufacturing within Southeast Asia.
• Prominent Japanese and Korean electronics companies, including Samsung, LG, Olympus, and Pioneer, established manufacturing factories in Vietnam.
• Numerous European and American apparel manufacturers also set up textile operations in the country, contributing to the industrial growth.
• In 2010, Intel inaugurated a $1 billion semiconductor chip factory in Vietnam, underscoring the country's strategic importance to the global business community.
• Economic growth in Vietnam has been broadly consistent with that of other developing countries, indicating steady progress within a comparable global context.
• The World Economic Forum’s Inclusive Development Index ranks Vietnam among countries that have notably advanced in becoming some of the world’s most inclusive economies.

• A significant indicator of this inclusivity is the high participation rate of women in the labor force, which is within 10% of that of men, a gender gap smaller than in many other countries, according to the World Bank.
• In 2015, households led by women in Vietnam were generally not poorer than those led by men, reflecting improved gender equity in economic conditions.
• Primary and secondary school enrollment rates for boys and girls in Vietnam are essentially equal, demonstrating gender parity in basic education access.
• More girls than boys continue their education into high school, indicating a positive trend in female educational attainment.
• The Vietnamese government is actively reviewing and adjusting policies to promote more equitable growth nationwide, as evidenced by the Development Strategy Action Plan 2011–2020.
• This strategy emphasizes leveraging the unique advantages of each region and fostering collaboration among regions to support and amplify development outcomes.
• In 2017, with assistance from the United Nations, Vietnam initiated groundwork to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) through the development of the "One Strategic Plan" (OSP).

• The OSP integrates the SDGs with Vietnam’s Socio-Economic Development Strategy (2011-2020) and Socio-Economic Development Plan (2016-2020), serving as a guideline for government agencies to implement SDGs effectively.

• The OSP focuses on key priority areas including investing in people, enhancing climate resilience and environmental sustainability, fostering prosperity and partnership, and promoting justice and inclusive governance.
• Vietnam has also formulated a National Action Plan to review and update current growth policies to align with the SDGs, ensuring policy coherence with sustainable development objectives.

• The development of this National Action Plan involved consultations with ministries, local governments, and various stakeholders to establish a unified framework for sustainable and inclusive growth.
• In 2011, the Business Software Alliance (BSA), also known as The Software Alliance, ranked Vietnam 53rd out of 66 countries on the IT Industry Competitiveness Index.
• According to the International Monetary Fund (IMF) in 2020, Vietnam's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) based on Purchasing Power Parity (PPP) was ranked 23rd out of 190 countries globally.
• The World Economic Forum's 2019 Global Competitiveness Report placed Vietnam at 67th position out of 141 countries, reflecting its competitive standing in the global economy.
• In 2018, the World Bank ranked Vietnam 68th out of 190 countries in its Ease of Doing Business index, indicating the relative ease or difficulty of conducting business in the country.
• The Heritage Foundation and The Wall Street Journal's 2019 Index of Economic Freedom ranked Vietnam 128th out of 180 countries, categorizing its economy as "mostly unfree" during that year.
• Transparency International's Corruption Perceptions Index in 2019 placed Vietnam 96th out of 177 countries, indicating the perceived level of public sector corruption within the country.
